review.title: Ultrametric Model of Mind, I: Review
review.abstract: We mathematically model Ignacio Matte Blanco's principles of {\em symmetric} and {\em asymmetric being} through use of an ultrametric topology. We use for this the highly regarded 1975 book of this Chilean psychiatrist and pyschoanalyst (born 1908, died 1995). Such an ultrametric model corresponds to hierarchical clustering in the empirical data, e.g. text. We show how an ultrametric topology can be used as a mathematical model for the structure of the logic that reflects or expresses Matte Blanco's symmetric being, and hence of the reasoning and thought processes involved in conscious reasoning or in reasoning that is lacking, perhaps entirely, in consciousness or awareness of itself. In a companion paper we study how symmetric (in the sense of Matte Blanco's) reasoning can be demarcated in a context of symmetric and asymmetric reasoning provided by narrative text.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Before introducing Matte Blanco's work in Section 3 and then discussing it in detail, Section 2 deals with alternative models of mental processes - geometry or topology of mental processes - which are neuronal model-centered and can therefore be considered influenced by physical models of the brain. They offer us a useful starting point because they also use ultrametric topological representations and processing frameworks. It will become clearer later that our primary motivation is not based on a physical (and therefore, let's assume, observable by physico-chemical and biological processes) view of the brain. Instead, our motivation is to have a processing framework to model human thinking based on data such as text or dialogue data or other behavioral signals. sections.heading: 5.3 Inducing an Ultrametric through Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering
sections.text: A mapping of the metric to ultrametry is achieved by an agglomerative hierarchical cluster algorithm, a well-established approach that depends on a cluster (compactness or connectedness or some other) criterion. If each of the n observations is considered a singleton node in the hierarchical tree, n − 1 agglomerations take place in pairs, resulting in a new node in the tree with each agglomeration. There is a redefinition of cluster distance (or, less restrictively, dissimilarity) following each agglomeration. Such a tree is dual or binary. A p-adic coding of observations can be read with each agglomeration (Murtagh, 2009, 2010b). The agglomerative algorithm outlined here is for computational efficiency reasons. Instead, the closest hierarchical coding of observations is an equivalent point between the places (Murtagh, 2009, 2010b).
